dom-formdata.summary: The FormData() constructor creates a new FormData object.
dom-formdata.title: FormData()

dom-formdata.summary: The FormData.entries() method returns an iterator allowing to go through all key/value pairs contained in this object. The key of each pair is a USVString object; the value either a USVString, or a Blob.
dom-formdata.title: FormData.entries()

dom-formdata.summary: The FormData.keys() method returns an iterator allowing to go through all keys contained in this object. The keys are USVString objects.
dom-formdata.title: FormData.keys()

dom-formdata.summary: The FormData.values() method returns an iterator allowing to go through all values contained in this object. The values are USVString or Blob objects.
dom-formdata.title: FormData.values()

dom-formdata-append.summary: The append() method of the FormData interface appends a new value onto an existing key inside a FormData object, or adds the key if it does not already exist.

firefox.notes: Prior to Firefox 7, specifying a Blob as the data to append to the object, the filename reported in the Content-Disposition HTTP header was an empty string, resulting in errors on some servers. Starting with Firefox 7, the filename blob is sent.

firefox_android.notes: Prior to Firefox 7, specifying a Blob as the data to append to the object, the filename reported in the Content-Disposition HTTP header was an empty string, resulting in errors on some servers. Starting with Firefox 7, the filename blob is sent.

ie.notes: With the "Include local directory pass when uploading files to a server" option enabled, IE will change the filename inside the Blob on the fly. To have direct control of the sent filename, the developer should send the filename as the third parameter value, i.e. formData.append(name, value, filename).

webview_android.notes: XHR in Android 4.0 sends empty content for FormData with blob.

dom-formdata-append.title: FormData.append()

dom-formdata-append.summary: The append() method of the FormData interface appends a new value onto an existing key inside a FormData object, or adds the key if it does not already exist.
dom-formdata-append.title: FormData.append()

dom-formdata-delete.summary: The delete() method of the FormData interface deletes a key and its value(s) from a FormData object.
dom-formdata-delete.title: FormData.delete()

dom-formdata-get.summary: The get() method of the FormData interface returns the first value associated with a given key from within a FormData object. If you expect multiple values and want all of them, use the getAll() method instead.
dom-formdata-get.title: FormData.get()

dom-formdata-getall.summary: The getAll() method of the FormData interface returns all the values associated with a given key from within a FormData object.
dom-formdata-getall.title: FormData.getAll()

dom-formdata-has.summary: The has() method of the FormData interface returns a boolean stating whether a FormData object contains a certain key.
dom-formdata-has.title: FormData.has()

dom-formdata-set.summary: The set() method of the FormData interface sets a new value for an existing key inside a FormData object, or adds the key/value if it does not already exist.
dom-formdata-set.title: FormData.set()

dom-progressevent-lengthcomputable.summary: The ProgressEvent.lengthComputable read-only property is a Boolean flag indicating if the resource concerned by the ProgressEvent has a length that can be calculated. If not, the ProgressEvent.total property has no significant value.
dom-progressevent-lengthcomputable.title: ProgressEvent.lengthComputable

dom-progressevent-loaded.summary: The ProgressEvent.loaded read-only property is an integer representing the amount of work already performed by the underlying process. The ratio of work done can be calculated with the property and ProgressEvent.total. When downloading a resource using HTTP, this only represent the part of the content itself, not headers and other overhead.
dom-progressevent-loaded.title: ProgressEvent.loaded

dom-progressevent-total.summary: The ProgressEvent.total read-only property is an integer representing the total amount of work that the underlying process is in the progress of performing. When downloading a resource using HTTP, this only represent the content itself, not headers and other overhead.
dom-progressevent-total.title: ProgressEvent.total

dom-xmlhttprequest-getresponseheader.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method getResponseHeader() returns the string containing the text of of a particular header's value.

firefox.notes: Starting from Firefox 49, empty headers are returned as empty strings in case the preference network.http.keep_empty_response_headers_as_empty_string is set to true, defaulting to false. Before Firefox 49 empty headers had been ignored. Since Firefox 50 the preference defaults to true.

firefox_android.notes: Starting from Firefox 49, empty headers are returned as empty strings in case the preference network.http.keep_empty_response_headers_as_empty_string is set to true, defaulting to false. Before Firefox 49 empty headers had been ignored. Since Firefox 50 the preference defaults to true.

dom-xmlhttprequest-getresponseheader.title: XMLHttpRequest.getResponseHeader()

handler-xhr-onabort.summary: The XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onabort is the function called when an XMLHttpRequest transaction is aborted, such as when the XMLHttpRequest.abort() function is called.
handler-xhr-onabort.title: XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onabort

handler-xhr-onerror.summary: The XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onerror is the function called when an XMLHttpRequest transaction fails due to an error.
handler-xhr-onerror.title: XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onerror

handler-xhr-onload.summary: The XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onload is the function called when an XMLHttpRequest transaction completes successfully.
handler-xhr-onload.title: XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onload

handler-xhr-onload.summary: The XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onprogress is the function called periodically with information when an XMLHttpRequest before success completely .
handler-xhr-onload.title: XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onprogress

handler-xhr-onloadstart.summary: The XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onloadstart is the function called when an XMLHttpRequest transaction starts transferring data.
handler-xhr-onloadstart.title: XMLHttpRequestEventTarget.onloadstart

handler-xhr-onreadystatechange.summary: An EventHandler that is called whenever the readyState attribute changes. The callback is called from the user interface thread. The XMLHttpRequest.onreadystatechange property contains the event handler to be called when the readystatechange event is fired, that is every time the readyState property of the XMLHttpRequest changes.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer version 5 and 6 supported ajax calls using ActiveXObject()

handler-xhr-onreadystatechange.title: XMLHttpRequest.onreadystatechange

interface-formdata.summary: The FormData interface provides a way to easily construct a set of key/value pairs representing form fields and their values, which can then be easily sent using the XMLHttpRequest.send() method. It uses the same format a form would use if the encoding type were set to "multipart/form-data".

firefox.notes: Prior to Firefox 7, specifying a Blob as the data to append to the object, the filename reported in the Content-Disposition HTTP header was an empty string, resulting in errors on some servers. Starting with Firefox 7, the filename blob is sent.

webview_android.notes: XHR in Android 4.0 sends empty content for FormData with blob.

interface-formdata.title: FormData

interface-formdata.summary: The FormData interface provides a way to easily construct a set of key/value pairs representing form fields and their values, which can then be easily sent using the XMLHttpRequest.send() method. It uses the same format a form would use if the encoding type were set to "multipart/form-data".
interface-formdata.title: FormData

interface-formdata.summary: The FormData interface provides a way to easily construct a set of key/value pairs representing form fields and their values, which can then be easily sent using the XMLHttpRequest.send() method. It uses the same format a form would use if the encoding type were set to "multipart/form-data".
interface-formdata.title: FormData

interface-progressevent.summary: The ProgressEvent interface represents events measuring progress of an underlying process, like an HTTP request (for an XMLHttpRequest, or the loading of the underlying resource of an img, audio, video, style or link).
interface-progressevent.title: ProgressEvent

interface-progresseventt.summary: The ProgressEvent() constructor returns a newly created ProgressEvent, representing the current completion of a long process.
interface-progresseventt.title: ProgressEvent()

states.summary: The XMLHttpRequest.readyState property returns the state an XMLHttpRequest client is in. An XHR client exists in one of the following states:
states.title: XMLHttpRequest.readyState

the-abort()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest.abort() method aborts the request if it has already been sent. When a request is aborted, its readyState is changed to XMLHttpRequest.UNSENT (0) and the request's status code is set to 0.
the-abort()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.abort()

the-getAllResponseHeaders()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method getAllResponseHeaders() returns all the response headers, separated by CRLF, as a string, or returns null if no response has been received.

firefox.notes: Starting from Firefox 49, empty headers are returned as empty strings in case the preference network.http.keep_empty_response_headers_as_empty_string is set to true, defaulting to false. Before Firefox 49 empty headers had been ignored. Since Firefox 50 the preference defaults to true.

firefox_android.notes: Starting from Firefox 49, empty headers are returned as empty strings in case the preference network.http.keep_empty_response_headers_as_empty_string is set to true, defaulting to false. Before Firefox 49 empty headers had been ignored. Since Firefox 50 the preference defaults to true.

the-getAllResponseHeaders()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.getAllResponseHeaders()

the-open()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method open() initializes a newly-created request, or re-initializes an existing one.

firefox.notes: Starting in Firefox 30, synchronous requests on the main thread have been deprecated due to their negative impact on performance and the user experience. Therefore, the async parameter may not be false except in a Worker.

firefox_android.notes: Starting in Firefox 30, synchronous requests on the main thread have been deprecated due to their negative impact on performance and the user experience. Therefore, the async parameter may not be false except in a Worker.

the-open()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.open()

the-overrideMimeType()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method overrideMimeType() specifies a MIME type other than the one provided by the server to be used instead when interpreting the data being transferred in a request.
the-overrideMimeType()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.overrideMimeType()

the-response-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest response property returns the response's body content as an ArrayBuffer, Blob, Document, JavaScript Object, or DOMString, depending on the value of the request's responseType property.
the-response-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.response

the-responsetext-attribute.summary: The read-only XMLHttpRequest property responseText returns the text received from a server following a request being sent.

ie.notes: Before IE 10, the value of XMLHttpRequest.responseText could be read only once the request was complete.

the-responsetext-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseText

the-responsetype-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest property responseType is an enumerated string value specifying the type of data contained in the response.
the-responsetype-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseType

the-responsetype-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest property responseType is an enumerated string value specifying the type of data contained in the response.
the-responsetype-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseType

the-responsetype-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest property responseType is an enumerated string value specifying the type of data contained in the response.
the-responsetype-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseType

the-responsetype-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest property responseType is an enumerated string value specifying the type of data contained in the response.
the-responsetype-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseType

the-responsetype-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest property responseType is an enumerated string value specifying the type of data contained in the response.
the-responsetype-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseType

the-responsetype-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest property responseType is an enumerated string value specifying the type of data contained in the response.
the-responsetype-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseType

the-responseurl-attribute.summary: The read-only XMLHttpRequest.responseURL property returns the serialized URL of the response or the empty string if the URL is null. If the URL is returned, any URL fragment present in the URL will be stripped away. The value of responseURL will be the final URL obtained after any redirects.
the-responseurl-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseURL

the-responsexml-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest.responseXML property is a read-only value which returns a Document containing the HTML or XML retrieved by the request, or null if the request was unsuccessful, has not yet been sent, or if the retrieved data can't be correctly parsed as XML or HTML. The response is parsed as if it were a "text/xml" stream. When the responseType is set to "document" and the request has been made asynchronously, the response is parsed as a "text/html" stream. responseXML is null for any other types of data, as well as for data: URLs.

firefox.notes: Prior to Firefox 51, an error parsing the received data added a <parsererror> node to the top of the Document and then returned the Document in whatever state it happens to be in. This was inconsistent with the specification. Starting with Firefox 51, this scenario now correctly returns null as per the spec.

firefox_android.notes: Prior to Firefox 51, an error parsing the received data added a <parsererror> node to the top of the Document and then returned the Document in whatever state it happens to be in. This was inconsistent with the specification. Starting with Firefox 51, this scenario now correctly returns null as per the spec.

the-responsexml-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.responseXML

the-send()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method send() sends the request to the server.
the-send()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.send()

the-send()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method send() sends the request to the server.
the-send()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.send()

the-send()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method send() sends the request to the server.
the-send()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.send()

the-send()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method send() sends the request to the server.
the-send()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.send()

the-send()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method send() sends the request to the server.
the-send()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.send()

the-send()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method send() sends the request to the server.
the-send()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.send()

the-setRequestHeader()-method.summary: The XMLHttpRequest method setRequestHeader() sets the value of an HTTP request header. When using setRequestHeader(), you must call it after calling open(), but before calling send(). If this method is called several times with the same header, the values are merged into one single request header.
the-setRequestHeader()-method.title: XMLHttpRequest.setRequestHeader()

the-status-attribute.summary: The read-only XMLHttpRequest.status property returns the numerical status code of the response of the XMLHttpRequest. status will be an unsigned short. Before the request is complete, the value of status will be 0. It is worth noting that browsers report a status of 0 in case of XMLHttpRequest errors too.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer version 5 and 6 supported ajax calls using ActiveXObject()

the-status-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.status

the-statustext-attribute.summary: The read-only XMLHttpRequest.statusText property returns a DOMString containing the response's status message as returned by the HTTP server. Unlike XMLHTTPRequest.status which indicates a numerical status code, this property contains the text of the response status, such as "OK" or "Not Found". If the request's readyState is in UNSENT or OPENED state, the value of statusText will be an empty string.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer version 5 and 6 supported ajax calls using ActiveXObject()

the-statustext-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.statusText

the-timeout-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest.timeout property is an unsigned long representing the number of milliseconds a request can take before automatically being terminated. The default value is 0, which means there is no timeout. Timeout shouldn't be used for synchronous XMLHttpRequests requests used in a document environment or it will throw an InvalidAccessError exception. When a timeout happens, a timeout event is fired.
the-timeout-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.timeout

the-upload-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest upload property returns an XMLHttpRequestUpload object that can be observed to monitor the progress of an upload.
the-upload-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.upload

the-withcredentials-attribute.summary: The XMLHttpRequest.withCredentials property is a Boolean that indicates whether or not cross-site Access-Control requests should be made using credentials such as cookies, authorization headers or TLS client certificates. Setting withCredentials has no effect on same-site requests.

firefox.notes: Starting with Firefox 11, it's no longer supported to use the withCredentials attribute when performing synchronous requests. Attempting to do so throws an NS_ERROR_DOM_INVALID_ACCESS_ERR exception.

firefox_android.notes: Starting with Firefox 11, it's no longer supported to use the withCredentials attribute when performing synchronous requests. Attempting to do so throws an NS_ERROR_DOM_INVALID_ACCESS_ERR exception.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer versions 8 and 9 supported cross-domain requests (CORS) using XDomainRequest

the-withcredentials-attribute.title: XMLHttpRequest.withCredentials
